author: Torrent_Studios
title: Cheap and decent alternative to The Goat Boat
review:
Introduction

From what I've seen online, 76207 Attack on New Asgard was not very well received by many LEGO Marvel fans. Some key complaints included being seemingly non-canon, and that none of the minifigures included were exclusive to this set, all of them found in the 76208 The Goat Boat. 

With that in mind, I was not expecting much when I purchased this set. I had wanted this set only for the figures and maybe the pieces, since I will not be able to afford the Goat Boat - my wallet has plans for the 2022 2HY Star Wars wave...

Having built the set though, my opinions have changed a bit.

Packaging

The box has a nice Thor: Love and Thunder-themed border, shared with 76208 The Goat Boat, and possibly future sets under the T:L&T subtheme!

On the right of the box you see Thor and Mighty Thor, (played by Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman respectively) with their eyes glowing blue.

Mighty Thor's hammer has noticeable cracks with blue lightning seeping through, and I wonder if Mighty Thor retrieved and repaired the pieces of the original Mjolnir (which was broken by Hela upon her introduction in Thor: Ragnarok). 

On the back right, the set is showcased at a different angle than the front, and the right side has a nice little contrast to the front with Thor and Mighty Thor's LEGO minifigures in their exact positions and stances as the front.

Contents and build process

Inside the box are two bags numbered 1 & 2 (number 1 being larger) that contain the 158 pieces, as well as an instruction manual with the box art and a QR code. Lastly, there is also a sticker sheet with 4 stickers, which are thankfully easily to apply.

It took me roughly 20 minutes to build everything at a leisurely pace.

Minifigures

For many buyers, the minifigures will undoubtedly be the highlights, although none of them are exclusive to this set.

Thor and Mighty Thor are found in Bag 1, and Gorr can be found in Bag 2.

Thor is a brand new minifigure.

The head piece is in 6 other sets to date. This set is the 7th to include it, and is the second cheapest, only behind 40525 Endgame Battle. 

The rest of the minifigure is new and excellent, with new torso and leg pieces that definitely resembles that of Ikaris (whose torso people used to make custom Thor minifigures). 

The build of Stormbreaker in this set is new, I believe. I can see some obvious improvements but the brown "branch" part should be longer. Also, the colour of the light bluish gray tile with clip doesn't really match up with the rest of the axe blade or the counterweight.

Mighty Thor is also a brand new minifigure.

She reuses a head piece originally designed for Jyn Erso in 2016, which has since appeared in 19 sets as a generic minifigure head for licensed themes, and is not particularly hard to obtain currently.

The rest of the minifigure is superb though. A new dual-molded hair-helmet combo element was designed for her, and it looks amazing. The torso and leg pieces are fully printed on both sides.

She wields Mjolnir, which at this point is a fairly common piece. Unfortunately, it isn't printed, which is a shame since it would've captured more of the cracks and lightning details. The Battle Dwarf minifigure from Collectable Minifigures Series 17 has shown that printing on the Mjolnir piece is possible, too.

Anyhow, both Thor and Mighty Thor have red capes which only have one neck hole, more commonly known as the "4+ cape". Also, both of them even have feet printing :)

The last minifigure is Gorr.

He is also decent, with a brand new head and torso that look mummified. His plain white legs are unprinted but they server their purpose well enough, despite being a little bland.

He wields a black sword. 

Build

The only model in this set is the "Shadow Monster". I don't think it appears in any of the promotion materials or trailers for Thor: Love and Thunder. Nevertheless, the pieces could prove useful.

There is reasonable articulation throughout the model, and I personally like the bulky base. The entire model is heavier than it looks, with a good amount of pieces forming the base. The two black 1x1 tiles are printed to represent the creature's eyes, and I can see those pieces being used by MOC builders. 

It's definitely not the best model ever, but I think it looks good among my collection.

I'm going to wait until I see the Thor: Love and Thunder movie in July, to decide what I'm going to do with this model. If it appears in the movie, I'll keep it built for a while until the Thor hype dies down a bit. 

If it doesn't appear, I'll be disassembling the model after I get home from the cinema so I can use the pieces in MOCs.

Overall

I'm not going to be spending my money on the Goat Boat, in an effort to save up for more Star Wars. However, I did want the minifigures, and the pieces were decent enough too, so I made this purchase. 

If you are a LEGO Marvel fan and have the budget for 76208 The Goat Boat, then you won't need this set for anything.

For casual fans like me, this set is a great little taste of the Thor: Love and Thunder theme.

I hope you found this review helpful and informative!
